title: couple same condition means cant
story: NewsCouple who CANT SMILE because of same rare condition get engaged after four datesAlex Barker and Erin Smith were born with rare Moebius syndrome which means they cant make any facial expressions and their speech is affectedShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video couple-who-cant-smile-due-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couple who found love over both having a rare condition which means they cant smile are engaged to be married - after just four dates.Alex Barker, , and Erin Smith, , were both born with Moebius syndrome, a rare condition which causes paralysis of the cranial nerves, meaning sufferers can not make any facial expressions. It also affects their speech, as well as their ability to move their eyes or even blink. Alex, from Coventry, says he knows when Erin is happy because she always puts her head on one side and says ooh.Erin, from North Carolina, in the US, added that its great having someone who understands her.Their condition is very rare, with only around  people with it in the UK and less than , worldwide. But Alex and Erin found love after meeting on a social media site for people with Moebius syndrome. And despite only meeting four times, they are already engaged.  Alex said: “If I meet people for the first time they might smile at me in greeting and then they are wondering why is he being rude  Why is he not smiling back  And I’m like I’m not smiling back because I actually can’t…I actually can’t do it. The main issue that I have is that I can’t show facial expression, so my speech is slightly slurred, and I can’t smile or express any emotion.As you can also see I don’t have all my fingers and I have not got all my toes either, so walking is quite dficult.  Growing up, Alex had a happy childhood until he reached his teens, when he was severely bullied. He said: I was the only disabled student and I got bullied and I hated it.It just made it really, really hard for me to cope and I was like, why have I been made like this  All my friends were getting girlfriends, I felt quite excluded from that. Dating was really, really hard.If you went onto a dating site and said, ‘look, I am a really nice guy, got my own house, got a good job, but one of the dficulties is that I can’t smile.’Its a bit of a relationship killer before it even gets started.”  But things have turned around for Alex after he found love with Erin. She said: At first, I would never have thought that I would ever fall in love with someone that was born with the same thing I was. But I mean it’s not just the Moebius, we have a lot of other things in common too. It is so nice to have someone that understands me for me.I love his British accent. It makes me melt. It does it just gives me chills. Being unable to smile at each other has meant that Alex and Erin have had to find other ways to communicate their feelings.  Alex explained: I can tell when Erin is happy because she always puts her head on one side and goes “ooh,” and I think although we can’t show facial expression, we know each other’s mannerisms, so when we’re upset or when we’re frustrated or whatever, there is a lot of nonverbal communication that goes on. I think the eyes tell a lot too, even not just Alex, but my family and friends have always said that they can look in my eyes and I smile with my eyes, they know I am happy. The couple have recently spoken to a specialist about the chances of passing on the condition to any future children.  Dr Jonathan Cole, who has studied Moebius syndrome for many years, said: With the genes,it were the same gene that you both had,it was a gene, then that would obviously increase the chance that any child that you had would have Moebius. If you had dferent genes they are likely to be very recessive and rare genes so the chances I would imagine would be less. But then you have to say, well, you have a child with Moebius, so you have a child with Moebius. And there again, who better to take care of a child with moebius, then two parents that have it  But for now, the lovebirds are focusing on their relationship. Alex said: Just having Erin’s hand in my hand, just means the world.It means we don’t have to show any facial expression. And I know when Erin is looking at me that there is a smile inside somewhere. Erin replied: There is a very big smile.- Body Bizarre is on Saturdays at pm on TLC UK.

story: NewsSchoolgirl, , sent mum a heartbreaking text and handed friend a sealed envelope before killing herselfUrsula Keogh gave her friend an envelope with a suicide note hours before her death, Bradford Coroners Court heardShareCommentsByNick LavigueurHana Carter:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsUrsula Keogh was discovered by police hours after she was reported missing "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn -year-old pupil described as clever but a little bit dark killed herself by jumping from a bridge, a coroner ruled today. Ursula Keogh was discovered by police in a river just a few hours after she was reported missing in January this year. The daughter of author and local radio presenter, Nicola Harlow, who said that she received a text from her daughter before she went missing that read: I love you, so sorry. It has now transpired that Ursula, whose mum described as older than her years and sensitive had been looking at suicide sites on Instagram and was self harming at the time. Her family attended the inquest at Bradford Coroners Court and were told by Coroner Martin Fleming that there was going to be a lot to take in, according to ExaminerLive . title: james bulgers mum left room
story: NewsJames Bulgers mum reduced to tears at TV show sympathetic to his killersDenise Fergus said she only found out Channel s James Bulger: The New Revelations was being made three weeks before it was broadcastShareByPaul Byrne_:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsDenise Fergus had to wait until the programme went out to learn of its revelations "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mother of murdered James Bulger has blasted TV bosses for failing to consult her over a documentary about her son’s death that was “too sympathetic” to his killers. Denise Fergus had to wait until the programme went out to learn of its revelations about her little boy’s case at the same time as millions of other viewers. And she was reduced to tears as James Bulger: The New Revelations raked over details of how two-year-old James was tortured to death by -year-olds Jon Venables and Robert Thompson in . She was furious that the Channel  show aired Thompson’s confidential parole papers, which her own legal team had been denied permission to see.  Denise, , said: “I didn’t know what to expect. I was on pins all day before [the broadcast].I didn’t know what I was going to see or hear in it.I felt like I was an outsider looking in on someone ’s story. I was fuming.He is my son, not theirs, and I was not allowed to see what they were saying about him. “I feel like they consider him their property. He is not a property. He was a little boy and he is mine.” Denise says she has complained to show bosses about the documentary, which she believes was too sympathetic towards the murderers. And she is also demanding an inquiry into how the confidential parole papers were broadcast on the show this week.  They contained statements from Thompson, who told of his “shame and revulsion” over the Liverpool murder as he made a bid for freedom in . Denise said: “Why were they allowed to see them and we weren’t  I want to know how they got them.” The Probation Service was not available for comment last night but it is understood bosses do not believe the leak came from their offices. Denise also felt the programme was biased towards the killers. She said: “I just felt it was all one-sided. They tried their best to get sympathy for them two.” And she felt it went into too much grisly detail, adding: “When they started going into detail about what they did to James, that’s when I had to leave the room.People know the details. They don’t need to hear it all the time. They didn’t have to do that. “I kept telling myself, ‘Don’t break, carry on watching, just get through this’, but it got too much in the end.”  After watching with husband Stuart, , at their home in Kirkby, Merseyside, Denise tweeted: “I’m upset, fuming with the one-sided sympathy with the evil killers of my beautul son.”Yesterday she added: “I think they’d already made their minds up about what they were going to show.” Thompson and Venables, now , were convicted  years ago this month over the murder of James and released on licence aged  with new secret identities.Thompson has led a largely unknown le since his release in . Venables is serving  months for possessing child abuse images, his second term for the offence. Channel  did not comment last night but it is understood the decision not to allow Denise to see an advance copy of the show was taken after legal advice. A spokeswoman for Denise said she only discovered the programme was being made three weeks before broadcast.After contacting the producers, she was then invited to “contribute”, by which time she felt it was too late.

story: NewsMystery as flowers taken from grave of parents and young sisters every weekA camera set up by a friend of Steve and Pat Russell and their daughters Kerry and Kirsty captured a man removing flowersShareCommentsByMichael MutchChris kitching:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video familys-horror-flowers-taken-grave-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSomeone keeps taking flowers and decorations from the grave of a mum and dad and their two young daughters, their devastated family and friends say. The tributes have been taken from the family grave of Steve and Pat Russell and their daughters Kerry and Kirsty nearly every week for the past seven months. A friend of the family hid a camera in a tree at the cemetery in Hull and captured images of a man picking up flowers and leaving on a bicycle. The friend told Hull Live that none of the other graves nearby have been disturbed, so this is personal.  Both Steve and Pat suffered the agony of losing their children Kerry and Kirsty at a young age due to a heart condition. Kerry died at the age of  after collapsing at school  years ago. Kirsty suffered from the same condition and died in  at the age of . Four years ago, Pat died after suffering a heart attack and her husband passed away a year later. Their ashes were placed at Eastern Cemetery in Hull underneath a rose bush next to their two daughters.  Allan Hiley, , from Halax, West Yorkshire, was “horried” when he was told by friends that someone was taking the flowers from their grave. He said: “Its the grave of my auntie and uncle and their two daughters. I come over every now and again to visit the grave and friends who knew them. They rang me up a while ago to tell me someone was taking the flowers and decorations. I was horried. “The love that family had between them was incredible and the fact that someone could be doing that to their grave is a farce.  “I was upset about it. They were a lovely family. They are not resting in peace because of this.” Friends of the family became concerned back in April with the missing flowers and decided that it was time to figure out what was going on. They placed a camera in a tree looking over the grave. One person, who did not wish to be named, said: “My we and her friends all visit the grave every week or so to put down flowers and other decorative items to make the grave look nice.  “We started to notice back in April that things were going missing and rang each other to figure out what was going on. Every so often we would go there and they were gone. “There are graves either side and around it that don’t get touched so this is personal. It’s just disgusting. Why would you do that to a grave  I can’t get my head around it. “Someone suggested to me to put a camera there to catch who was doing it. So I purchased one and hid it in a nearby tree.” On September  the camera had recorded footage of a man no one could recognise visiting the grave. He can be seen standing in front of the plot with his bicycle before picking up a bunch of flowers and tipping the water on the ground.Pictures taken by the camera also show the flowers missing from the grave two minutes after he arrived. The footage was reported to Humberside Police. The same man was seen again visiting the grave on the evening of November , and shortly after his arrival the flowers were no longer there. Hull City Council has confirmed that they would not have removed the flowers from the plot.

title: passenger sues british airways after
story: NewsPassenger sues British Airways after sitting next to -stone man for  hoursStephen Prosser, , claims he suffered soft tissue damage from sitting next to the passenger during the long-haul flight from Bangkok to London HeathrowShareByElaine McCahill:,  NOV NewsStephen Prosser, , is suing British Airways for £, claiming he suffered soft tissue damage after being next to a -stone man on a -hour flight "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA passenger is suing British Airways after being sat next to a -stone man on a  hour flight. The businessman claims his back was injured after having to sit next to the overweight inidual. Stephen Prosser, , who works as a company director, claims he suffered soft tissue damage after the man wedged himself into the seat next to him. The pair were given seats by BA next to each other on the -hour flight from Bangkok airport in Thailand to London Heathrow on January , . Mr Prosser, who is only ft in, claims that the obese passenger was so large that his body fat spilled into his seat by several inches.  The freelance civil engineer said he was crushed against the side of the plane by a ft in man weighing -stone. His lawyers say Mr Prosser was forced to adjust his body and sit in an awkward and uncomfortable position for the whole  hour and  minute flight. Mr Prosser says he was left suffering symptoms from his injuries for the following three months - and is now seeking damages. But British Airways deny the claims - stating Mr Prosser did not not display any signs of injury when leaving the flight. Dad-of-two Mr Prosser said: Id spent Christmas  with some friends in Thailand and was ing home on January , . Id paid over pound, for the flight and usually I fly Thai Airways but because BA had a sale on and were cheaper I went with them. Just as the plane door was about to close, this ft in elk, weighing about -stone got on-board and sat between myself and another passenger who had the aisle seat. He was a huge bloke, not just overweight but really big boned as well. He was a real lump. I felt discomfort as soon as he sat down because I was pinned against the side of the cabin. Im only about ft in and weigh  stone. I suffered problems with my posture -years ago when I used to drive to Kent for work every week so I knew I was in trouble straight away. As soon as the plane had taken off and we were allowed out of our seats I took the matter up with the flight attendants. I asked whether they could move him or move me but it was a full flight and they decided not to move me to a crew members seat because Id have to keep on getting up to allow them to get to the galley.  They said there wasnt anything they could do so I said I wanted to make a formal complaint which I did with the on-board customer services rep. I had no choice but to go back to my seat and the discomfort at being squashed up against the cabin soon turned to agony. To be honest the big guy looked in pain himself as he had his knees wedged into the seat in front so I didnt want to bother him personally. I think its up to the staff to take control of a situation like that and they should have asked the passenger on the aisle seat to swap with the larger man in the middle. But they didnt and I ended up doing a lot of damage to my back over the course of a nightmare -hours. Mr Prosser says he continued to see a chiropractor up until May this year. Defence documents to the claim show Mr Prosser was sitting in a window seat on the plane and the obese passenger was in the middle seat. Immediately after take-off Mr Prosser asked to speak to the Customer Service Manager and refused to sit in his seat. The airline manager was under the impression he wanted an upgrade and told him the flight was full. Mr Prosser told the manager he would have back pain and would not be able to go to workhe wasnt moved. But the manager found the comments surprising after it was less than half an hour after take-off.  The manager said the passenger next to Mr Prosser was well built and over six feet tall, but certainly not fat. British Airways say the passenger did not have fat which was spilling over the arm rest. Mr Prosser, of Tonypandy, South Wales, was offered extra pillows and blankets to support his back - which he accepted. He is claiming between pound, and pound, as general damages for pain, suffering and loss of amenity. The case is set to be heard at Pontypridd County Court on Friday. Before the hearing, a spokeswoman for BA said: As the case is subject to ongoing proceedings, it would be inappropriate for us to comment.

title: sucking your childs dummy clean
story: NewsWhy sucking your childs dummy clean could actually be good for their healthInstead of passing on germs, sucking your childs dummy to clean it can be beneficial for their healthShareCommentsByHayley Coyle:,  NOV NewsNew research shows cleaning your childs dummy is actually beneficial "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParents who suck on their childs dummy to clean it could actually be passing health benefits on to them, scientists have suggested. Instead of passing on germs, experts say that the habit may result in the “transfer of healthy micro-organisms” to their young offspring. The study, by Henry Ford Health System in Detroit, involved interviews with  mothers. Of the  per cent who reported their child currently using a dummy,  per cent said the parents sucked the dummy to clean it.  The author of the small American study said they found those children to have lower levels of Immunoglobulin E , an antibody related to allergic responses in the body. High IgE levels typically indicate a greater risk of having allergies and allergic asthma, lead author Eliane Abou-Jaoude said. Co-author Edward Zoratti said: We found that parental pacier sucking was linked to suppressed IgE levels beginning around  months, and continued through  months. How to prevent common cold - doctor reveals eight simple tips to avoid virusFurther research is needed, but we believe the effect may be due to the transfer of health-promoting microbes from the parents mouth. It is unclear whether the lower IgE production seen among these children continues into later years.  Scientists cautioned that the study, being presented at the American College of Allergy, Asthma and ImmunologyAnnual Scientic Meeting in Seattle, required more research. Dr Abou-Jaoude said that while it indicated an association between parental pacier sucking and children with lower IgE levels, it does not necessarily mean the practice itself causes the lower levels.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Beast from the East to freeze UK from TOMORROWTemperatures are set to plunge in many parts of the country as a bone-chilling cold front moves in from RussiaShareCommentsByNeil MurphyElaine McCahillLuke Kenton:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video getting-bit-colder-watch-weather-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain will be gripped by freezing weather from tomorrow as a bone-chilling cold front moves in from Russia leaving the UK colder than Moscow. The Met Office has warned that the big freeze will send temperatures plummeting after yesterdays balmy conditions. The so-called Beast from the East will be accompanied by biting winds as it engulfs this weeks high pressure front. It will feel like -C in London by next Thursday, -C Birmingham, Manchester -, while Scotland will feel the coldest with a wind chill of -, according to Net Weather . The rest of the week will will see temperatures hover at around C as wintery conditions begin to take hold.  Martin Bowles, an Operational Meteorologist with the Met Office, told : Temperatures will be below average and the top of the mountains in northern Scotland might well get snow. There will be some light frosts quite widely around the country. We will start to get an east wind from Poland and Russia, so while the official temperature is C, it will feel like C or C sometimes. it will be quite cold.” Forecasters warn the UK could be hit by bitter blizzards at the end of the month.  The blizzards could bring fierce snowfall, plummeting temperatures and severe transport disruption. Piers Corbyn, forecaster for WeatherAction, said: “An active low-pressure system will move in from the northwest next week signalling a change to much colder conditions. “We are expecting this to bring some early winter weather with heavy snow and very cold winds in the north and a risk of wintry showers even across southern Britain.” The plume of freezing air, which is to sweep in from Scandinavia, could linger throughout December and into , forecasters say. Mr Corbyn added: “This pattern is likely to hold out through the rest of the month and into December with a risk of blizzards in Scotland and the north and widespread snow showers.  “There will be a risk of travel disruption through this period with volatile, stormy weather combined with the cold brining a risk of winter thunderstorms and outbreaks of thunder snow. “What we are looking at is a pattern of circulation similar to that which was observed during the mini ice-age.” The historic Mini Ice Age which occurred during the mid-th century and saw Britons hold frost fairs on the frozen River Thames. The Met Office says theyll be an increased chance of snow in the coming weeks. Its website reads: With more generally colder temperatures, there will be an increased chance of snow, particularly for northern hills, during spells of more unsettled weather.

title: woman told headache caused trapped
story: NewsWoman told her headache was caused by trapped nerves dies of brain tumourAmanda Robertson, , was in and out of hospital as she suffered from severe headaches, nosebleeds and vomitingShareCommentsBySarah Ward:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsAmanda Robertson died at home in September  "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who was told that her headache was caused by trapped nerves was later diagnosed with a brain tumour that killed her, her devastated parents say. Amanda Robertson, , was in and out of hospital as she suffered from severe headaches, nosebleeds and vomiting. Her parents Caroline and Monty say she underwent a CT scan and she was sent home with painkillers after a neurologist said her headache was caused by trapped nerves. But the parents say opportunities to spot the benign tumour on the scan - and provide treatment that would have saved her - were missed. Theyve now accused NHS bosses of killing their daughter and received a settlement over the case, Daily Record reports.  A report found that Amanda would have had a  per cent chance of survival had the tumour been spotted on the CT scan, which was performed after four hospital admissions in nine months The parents, who cared for their daughter full-time at home due to her autism, said they pleaded with staff to perform an MRI scan. But they claim it was only agreed to weeks later when Amandas condition took a turn for the worse. Amanda died at home less than a week before the scheduled appointment, on September ,  - just six days before her scan at Raigmore Hospital, Inverness. The parents say their grief was compounded when it was later established the tumour could have been spotted at the time of the first CT scan. This month, four years after Amandas death, her parents have won legal action against NHS Highland and spoke publicly for the first time. Caroline, , said: Its hard enough dealing with the death of your child, but when its caused by the very professionals who are there to help then it makes it all the worse. Amanda would still be alivestaff at Raigmore simply did their job.  As far as were concerned NHS Highland killed our daughter and ripped our world apart. I was very scared about what was happening to her. She was in a lot of pain and couldnt get out of bed - my husband and I basically carried her into hospital. Seeing her suffer was agonising and left us all in a constant state of fear. Your mind starts going round and round and you dont know what to think or do. We were also in a catch  because the hospital kept letting us down but we had nowhere  to go. In December , Amanda told her GP she was suffering from headaches, nosebleeds, balance issues and a suspected lump in the back of her head, her parents said. They said she was referred to an ENT consultant who removed a nasal ulcer in February  and suggested sinus issues were the cause of the headaches. But on July , her headaches ed so the same specialist ordered a CT scan. A fortnight later, on July , she was given the all clear, her parents say. But the vomiting and headaches continued and after Amandas lips turned white on July , she was readmitted to hospital. On August  a neurologist from NHS Highland examined her and diagnosed occipital nerve neuralgia , the Robertsons said.  Amanda was scheduled to be released three days later but on August  was violently sick, and a doctor who witnessed her distress pushed for an MRI scan to be carried out, her parents said. When a date of September  was planned, Caroline said she complained it was too long to wait and urged for an earlier appointment to be booked. Amanda died at home six days before her scan, with the cause of death was confirmed as a tumour on the central nervous system within the brain, her parents say. The family, from Alness, Ross and Cromarty, complained to the Scottish Public Services Ombudsman who ruled thatthe tumour had been discovered in July or early August it would have been operable. A report said there would have been a  per cent chance of recovery from the benign tumour. NHS Highland was given  recommendations to improve patient care and was criticised for its lack of focus on the failings and ways to improve their services. The General Medical Council also investigated the family GP who failed to spot the early warning signs and handed down advice. Amandas dad Monty, , a retired oil rig fabricator, added: We begged that neurologist for an MRI and he said there was no need - then he just left. The hospital had loads of chances and time to act but did nothing. We cannot allow this kind of flippant approach to healthcare to go unchecked. Anyone who played a part in Amandas death needs to be held to account, at the very least so that standards improve and other families dont go through what we have. NHS Highland can no longer pretend to care about people - not when they refuse to help then drag innocent people through legal processes. Sue Grant, partner at Digby Brown Solicitors and head of clinical negligence, helped secure an undisclosed settlement for the Robertson family. She said: This was a very tragic and traumatic experience for the Robertson family. It would be inappropriate to comment on their case but I can confirm their civil action has now concluded and I hope they may now be able to rebuild their future. NHS Highland has been contacted for comment.

story: NewsLeukaemia-stricken boy, , who warmed hearts as Batman is now cancer freeMiles Scott dressed as his favourite superhero and took over San Francisco, Calornia, in heartbreaking photosShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsScott Miles dressed as BatKid in San Francisco "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA leukaemia-stricken boy who warmed hearts all over the world in poignant snaps in his Batman costume is now cancer-free. Miles Scott, , was his favourite superhero for a day and took on San Francisco, Calornia. He was just five back then in  and, as had the leukaemia, the Make-A-Wish Foundation transformed the city streets into Gotham. But little Miles has been in remission for five years now, a milestone which for many is the point when a patient is considered cured. He’s doing great, a Make-A-Wish spokesman said. Remission means that no leukaemic cells can be found in the blood or bone marrow and the bone marrow is working normally again.  Hes now in fth gradeand loves science, robotics and baseball, his family said. He also likes to help with work on their farm. The charity spokesman added: Miles brought smiles and hope to children living with le threatening medical conditions in San Francisco and all over the world. San Francisco is proud to have been a part of this once in a letime event. Miles, from Oregon, was diagnosed with leukemia when he was just  months old.

title: hand grenade pestle clueless man
story: NewsClueless man used grenade as pestle thinking explosive was a propIt is believed the hand grenade could be more than  years old - but the person who found it used it to grind chillisShareByScott Feng:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsThe used the explosive as a pestle to grind chillli "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A clueless man used a hand grenade as a pestle to crush chilli peppers after believing the decades-old explosive was a prop.Mr Zeng found the dangerous explosive device in a bag underground after unearthing it during renovations in the village of Guanzhai in south-western China’s Guizhou Province. He said his garden hoe struck something solid, and he opened the bag to find the rusty hand grenade inside thought to be from the Chinese Civil Waror the Second Sino-Japanese War . Mr Zeng said he was shocked but quickly brushed off the possibility of it being real. He believed it to be a prop used for military training like similar duds he used to throw during his school days.The following morning, he told village party secretary Song Youxue, who was so scared he immediately called the police and handed it over to a bomb squad for inspection. Mr, who is in his s,Zeng is said to have been terried when the authorities confirmed it to be a real hand grenade.The police will reportedly dispose of the device safely.

title: real life narco dubbed the
story: NewsBritish Narcos reveal part in battle to stop Pablo Escobars Colombian drug cartelEXCLUSIVE: They werent shown in the Netflix dramatisation but a team from the UK seized a record £billion haul of drugs in BogotaShareCommentsByTom Pettor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsTom Chandler outside a burning cocaine lab during a jungle raid with the Colombian Antinarcotics Police."Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGiven the perilous task of taking on the most powerful organised crime gangs in history, Tom Chandler had the odds stacked against him in almost every way. But his small British team had remarkable success against the murderous drug cartels in Colombia. The ex-VAT inspector’s unit could not compete in terms of size with the US authorities fighting the same battle. Yet the Brits masterminded the seizure of a record poundbillion worth of drugs. And while the gung-ho American narcotics agents publicly bragged about triumphs, Tom and his team went about things in a typically understated British way by keeping their exploits quiet. Only now is he lting the lid on his time in capital Bogota, starting in .  Speaking to the Mirror in a London pub, Tom said: “We were the British equivalent of Narcos. Everyone’s heard of the DEA [the US Drug Enforcement Administration] and the US agencies doing their stuff in Colombia, and the reason is because they talk about it. “They would say after a seizure that it was down to the DEA in Bogota and straight away the bad guys would go looking for the informant. “We never claimed a single result. No one even knew the Brits were there, because we didn’t want them to. We weren’t egotists. “Our idea was to let others take the credit and keep our heads down. The DEA were looking for glory. This is the first time the British story has been told.”  Now in his s, Tom grew up in Seaham, Co Durham. He joined HM Customs and Excise after studying languages, in the hope of finding adventure abroad. But he was sent to be a VAT inspector in Birmingham. When bosses gave him the job as a drug liaison officer in Bogota  years ago, it was in violent chaos. Weeks earlier Medellin Cartel boss Pablo Escobar – responsible for an estimated , to , deaths during a reign of terror that included the bombing of Avianca Flight , which claimed  lives in  – had been killed by police in a rooftop shootout. The Cali Cartel then took over as the dominant cocaine gang. The Americans, who had dozens of DEA officers there, aimed to take out the top brass of the cartels, one by one.  Tom could not replicate this because the UK did not have the resources there – he had just a handful of staff. Instead he wooed informants – including a prostitute who gleaned information during pillow talk – and found out about shipments before they left. Targeting the ports was something that had never been done. Based in the British embassy, Tom and his network penetrated the crews who raced coke-laden speed boats across the Caribbean sea and identied “motherships” carrying tonnes of the drug to Europe.  Tom – not his real name – developed a network of  informants who helped to intercept  tonnes of drugs. No investigator in history is thought to have been behind more seizures. Corruption was re. Workers were being offered – as Escobarsays in the hit Netflix drama series Narcos, “plata o plomo” – meaning, silver or lead. Most took the money rather than the bullet, so Tom had to offer cash. He added: “The Cali and North Valley cartels were the biggest organised crime groups in history. “Their intelligence services were so far ahead of anything that any other country had in that region, let alone crime organisation. The capabilities of the bad guys was terrying.  Tom, who has revealed his story in his new book Narco Wars, arranged customs training courses as a cover for meeting port staff, and urged them to work for the British government. After spending months grooming a customs inspector in the port of Cartagena, Tom asked the man for information and got a chilling reply. The man said: “If you repeat what you have said to me to anyone  around here, it will get you killed. “You are a nice guy. So I’m going to forget what you said and pretend that I never heard it... I think you are going to get yourself killed.”  While Tom survived, others did not. A key informant was shot dead by hitmen after a friend betrayed him. Tom said: “He had a we and kids, and he didn’t deserve to die. To some extent I was to blame.” Drug lords vowed to hunt down “the Brit” as he became known, but Tom rejected calls toto the UK. He said: “London said come home for six months... but I had invested so much work building up the sources. If I went home I might lose them. I had to plead with London to let me carry on.” It all ended in the early s, when new laws made handling informants impossible abroad. Stopping the flow of drugs into the UK is now down to the National Crime Agency. Recent figures show drug seizures are down to the lowest level in  years. And while alleged Mexican drug lord Joaquin “El Chapo” Guzman is on trial in the US, Tom believes the war on drugs has failed. He added: “A lot of [my] friends have died. Was it worth it  No, because we are no better off... The war will not be won with bullets. It can only be won through education and mass media and social media campaigns. These are our most powerful weapons.”Narco Wars is published by Milo Books, priced pound..

title: woman who thought vampire tv
story: NewsWoman who thought she was Vampire Diaries character stabs werewolf lover in chestThe Vampire Diaries fan Ekaterina Tirskaya told the victim she was on a mission to kill werewolves and kned him as he got out of the bathShareCommentsByWill Stewart:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsEkaterina Tirskaya, , has been jailed for attacking the man with a kne "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who thought she was a vampire from a long-running TV series stabbed her new lover in the chest thinking he was a werewolf, it is claimed. Ekaterina Tirskaya, , told police that she believed she was Elena Gilbert, a fictional character in US television fantasy drama The Vampire Diaries. She and her lover had slept together for the first time after meeting on social media, a court was told. The victim told her that he didn’t believe in the supernatural, and urged her to go home. But she grabbed a kne and attacked him as he was getting out of the bath, according to reports.  Tirskaya, from Novosibirsk, Russia, has been jailed for the kne attack. Psychological assessments ahead of her trial in Siberia found the hair treatment specialist to be sane, it was reported. The morning after sleeping with the man, the woman suddenly “changed”, telling him she was a vampire and like Elena Gilbert, played by Canadian actress Nina Dobrev, she had a mission to kill werewolves.  One report said: “She grabbed a kne in the kitchen and suddenly attacked him when he was getting out of the bath. “He managed to get hold of the kne. “But she grabbed another one and stabbed him in the chest.”  He staggered out of his flat and banged on neighbours doors pleading for help. They called an ambulance and police. The man was gravely wounded but survived the February attack. Prosecutor Felix Kuznetsov said Tirskaya was sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison after being found guilty of inflicting grievous bodily harm. She was also ordered to pay pound, in “moral damages” to her stabbed lover.

title: developer vows to persevere after dundee council refuses homes plans
story: A developer whose bid to build housing on a former Dundee factory site was rejected has vowed to persevere with the plans.FH Developments said it was “% committed to finding an acceptable solution for all involved” after councillors voted to refuse planning consent to develop the former Tay Rope Works site on Magdalen Yard, in the West End council ward.The proposals involved building five houses and four flats, as well as demolishing a C-listed facade.A spokeswoman for FH Developments said: “Before we purchased the site, it had lain empty for about  years and had been left to lapse into its present derelict condition.“For clarity, FH Developments has only owned the site for  months and is far from responsible for the deterioration of the building over the last  years.”The spokeswoman said the firm had invested £, since buying the old rope works – describing it as a “considerable amount” for a site that already has a live planning consent.“It is felt that the demolition of the rotten facade is a priority as there are health and safety issues due to the building’s dangerous condition,” she added.

title: dundee boss jim hails the impact of new signing martin woods
story: Jim McIntyre hailed the impact of new signing Martin Woods on his full debut in the - draw with St Mirren.And the Dundee boss is hoping the former Ross County midfielder can build a telling partnership with Glen Kamara in the middle of the park.The Dens boss thought the two complemented each other well against the Buddies and was impressed with Woods’ staying power, playing  minutes in his first start since May.He said: “Martin was really struggling in the last  minutes.“He felt a wee bit of tightness in his hamstring as well.“He just managed through it to the end as we had made all our subs by then.“But I thought considering he has not been involved in a team structure, then he did remarkably well.“He used his experience and I thought him and Glen looked very strong together.“I don’t want sitting midfielders, I want them to be getting up and around the box.“I thought on Saturday, Glen and Woods really complemented each other, they were excellent.”Woods, meanwhile, is one of a number of players the physio is keeping an eye on over the international break.The Dundee boss added: “Woods has a tight hamstring and Benjy Kallman has a bit of fluid on his knee so we will see how that settles down.“Andy Boyle’s stitches are in a really awkward place on his kneecap.“If you burst the stitches it can take a long time so we have been really careful with him.“Roarie Deacon has a thigh strain but we think it is not as bad as the problem he had previously so, hopefully, we will see him sooner rather than later.”

title: dundee community cafe in christmas plea for childrens toys clothing and household items
story: A community cafe has launched a Christmas charity drive for children’s toys, clothing and other household items.R  R cafe, which operates out of Coldside Parish Church every Friday, has asked big-hearted residents to look out items before a party next month.The centre provides a safe space for people in recovery to meet others in the same situation.Volunteers hope to present children with the gts on December , when Santa himself is scheduled to make a visit.Celia Ramsay, who has been with the group for five years, said: “We’re looking for toys, clothes, bedding, curtains, anything really that can make things feel a bit more homely. People can drop items in at the church or have larger things collected.“Donations will go towards families in recovery, under-privileged children, or anyone who needs a bit of support.”

title: dundee defender kerr waddell extends morton loan spell
story: Defender Kerr Waddell has extended his loan spell at Morton, Dundee have confirmed.Then-Morton boss Ray McKinnon took Waddell on loan at the start of the season and although the former Dundee United manager quickly moved to Falkirk, the centre half has featured regularly for The Ton.That left their management team of Jonatan Johansson and Peter Houston keen to hold on to him until the end of the campaign.Dundee have been agreeable to that but they see the -year-old as having a big future at Dens Park.Taking to social media Waddell voiced his pleasure at completing the deal.He wrote on Twitter: #Delighted to be staying here till the end of the season, loved every minute so far.#Waddell will now be eligible to play for Morton in the Scottish Cup this season.

title: dundee people 29000 raised for maggies centres
story: A team of accountancy staff has raised almost £, for Maggie’s Centres this year, with the latest effort being a celebratory charity ball.About  guests attended EQ Chartered Accountants’ first charity ball at the Apex City Quay Hotel and Spa.With a silent auction, raffle and ious games, guests raised a total of £, on the night alone which, combined with a host of other activities and events held so far this year, brings the current total to £,.Since the start of the year, staff from EQ’s four offices – in Dundee, Forfar, Cupar and Glenrothes – have held bake sales, race nights and pub quizzes and taken part in a skye and a number of gruelling fitness challenges.Annie Long, fundraising manager at Maggie’s Dundee, said: “We are absolutely delighted by EQ’s contribution to Maggie’s Centres and so touched by their achievements throughout the year.#These funds will help ensure our centres continue toand make an impact on each person who walks through our doors.”

title: dundee people volunteers attend reception at no 10
story: Prime Minister Theresa May has personally thanked volunteers for the MS Society – including Lillian Malcolm from Dundee – at a special reception at Downing Street.The event celebrated the impact volunteers and many others have had on vital MSresearch and driving more, improved treatments for everyone, as well as the support they give to thousands of people living with MS. vw, px"  Members of MS Society Scotland from Dundee, Angus, the Borders and Aberdeenshire attended.Lillian, , who was diagnosed with MS in , has been volunteering for the MS Society for  years.She said: “MS runs in my family – my sister had it and my first cousin also lives with it as well as quite a few more distant relatives. I have a big extended family and I wouldn’t want any of them to get an incurable disease.”Mrs May, said: “I was inspired to hear of Lillian’s incredible contribution to the MS Society in Dundee.”

title: i felt suicidal dundee woman 36 bullied for having red hair
story: As a young woman she was taunted and teased for no reason other than the fact she had red hair. vw, px"  The bullying and abuse got so bad that at times a teenage Leanne believed the only way she could escape from her tormentors would be to kill herself.The psychological impact of her ordeal led to her being diagnosed with borderline personality disorder.And tragically for the -year-old civil servant from Menzieshill, the bullying she endured as a child has followed her into adulthood.Today Leanne – not her real name – spoke out as part of Anti-Bullying Week  to try to persuade others not to suffer in silence eventhey are struggling to find the strength to speak out.The name-calling she was subjected to haunts her to this day and has had a profound impact on the rest of her le.She revealed: “One of the reasons I don’t have children of my own is because I was so badly bullied as a child, all because I had red hair.“Ginger ferret, ginger freak and ginger fuzzy hair were just some of the names I was called.“At one point in secondary school I felt suicidal, it was so bad. I ended up being diagnosed with borderline personality disorder.“My bullying was all mental but it had a devastating affect on me. It has taken me a long time but I finally feel I am dealing with it and I want to speak out to say that bullying is never OK.”Mental health nurse Ash Mullen knows knows only too well the impact bullies can on children and families.She recently set up the Let’s Talk Tayside Group, which in only a few weeks has given thousands of people a forum to speak about issues affecting their lives.Ash said: “There are people in the group now talking about bullying they have suffered and I personally know how traumatic this can be for families.“My own -year-old daughter was the victim of bullying at school in Dundee earlier this year. She was physically attacked and it left her terried and traumatised.“Bullying is never acceptable and can affect people for a long time. We need to banish bullying.”Dundee City Council’s education convener, Stewart Hunter, said: “A lot of work is going on in our schools. We recognise we have had bullying issues but are working with pupils and parents to try to eradicate it.“One initiative proving very successful is peer mentoring. We have been bringing primary children into secondary schools and getting senior pupils to talk to them about the impact of bullying.“We find it’s much easier for younger pupils to approach a senior one with their concerns rather than going to an adult.“The senior pupils have had training and know how to help. We are also asking parents to be pro-active. A lot of bullying goes on outside school because of social media.“We’re getting parents into schools and educating them about what can go on and showing them what to look out for. We want parents to come to usthey are concerned and before the bullying goes too far.”David Baxter, of the local branch of the EIS, said: “We are taking part in a lot of good work with the education department to address bullying.#One of the big issues is that bullying has moved out of the playground and classroom and gone behind closed doors. We’re trying to show pupils and parent how to deal with this.”

title: loganair and emirates agree deal for money saving travel from dundee airport
story: Loganair has signed an agreement with airline giant Emirates, which could save money for passengers travelling around the world from Dundee Airport. vw, px"  The two companies have signed an interline agreement meaning customers can travel from Dundee via London Stansted to Emirates’ network of  destinations around the world on a single ticket.It also means passengers flying from Dundee to London and onward to international destinations will save an Air Passenger Dutycharge of £ in Economy Class or £ in Business Class – charges which must be paid when departing from Edinburgh where APD applies.The interline agreement is live with immediate effect, meaning flights are bookable at emirates and via travel agents.Kay Ryan, Loganair’s commercial director, said: “Emirates is a leader in international air travel and we’re thrilled to welcome them into our Better-Connected programme.#The agreement means Dundee Airport is now not only connected to London Stansted for journeys to and from London, but now a local airport for global travel.”

title: michelin dundee hosts meeting preparing young people in city for work
story: More than  people from the Dundee business community attended a breakfast meeting hosted by Michelin yesterday when they learned how they could have a role in preparing young people in the city for the world of work. vw, px"  The event – also attended by secondary school pupils – was a joint venture between Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, Career Ready, Breakthrough and Developing the Young Workforce Dundee and Angus .Breakthrough and Career Ready are newly-established in Dundee and the support of local businesses and volunteer mentors who believe in helping young people reach their potential is crucial for both organisations.Alison Henderson, chief executive of the chamber of commerce, who chaired the event, said: “I am passionate that business is given an opportunity to connect with young people.”

title: no discussions over glen kamara deal as time running out for finn at dundee
story: The future of Dundee’s star midfielder Glen Kamara remains unclear with only months remaining on his contract.The -year-old has joined the Finnish international squad for their crucial Nations League clashes with Greece and Hungary.However, his future at Dens Park may be coming to an end with manager Jim McIntyre admitting there has been no talks over any extension.He said: “We have not had that conversation yet.“I know there has been interest in him. He is a very good player and I can understand the interest.“All we are doing right at this moment is assessing what we have got and then moving forward there will be discussions.”With plenty of speculation over a transfer in the summer with clubs like Sunderland, Rangers, Celtic, Hearts and Hibs credited with interest in his services, suitors in the January window won’t be hard to find.Meanwhile, the Dark Blues are hoping injured central defender Josh Meekings won’t need surgery on his troublesome hip that would mean the end of his season.The -year-old has been out of action since the start of September but the club hope a further injection in the injury will sort the issue without needing to go under the kne.He said: “Meekings is having another injection and we will take it from there.“But there is the possibility he could face further surgery whichthat was the case, he would be out for the season.“Hopefully, the conservative treatment of having a jag will get him through it.”Martin Woods , Benjy Kallman , Andy Boyleand Roarie Deaconall have knocks but aren’t expected to be missing for the trip to Hibs next week.

title: ross county co boss stuart kettlewell says dundee united lack class
story: Stuart Kettlewell has accused Dundee United of lacking class.The Ross County co-boss was angry after his side were defeated - by Robbie Neilson#s rejuvenated men.He accused United of ing in a game that saw Paul McMullan booked in the first half for playacting.“They have done a number on us,” Kettlewell said.“I’m a football person and I like my football. So, when you see people throw themselves on the ground continuously, then that’s not football to me.“You know, that wee lack of class in terms of winning . . . we went down to Tannadice and won - earlier in the season.“We round our players up, we take them into the dressing-room and we continue with the rest of the season.”

title: st mirren showing has to be minimum level for us to avoid drop says dundee winger ralph
story: Saturday’s improved performance against St Mirren is the minimum level Dundee can allow themselvesthey have any chance of avoiding relegation, according to defender Nathan Ralph.The Dark Blues felt they let the Buddies off the hook at Dens Park at the weekend in the - draw in what the full-back called one of their best displays of the season.And he insists that has to be the standard they maintain for the rest of the campaign.Ralph said: “I think it was a chance missed. I felt like we played as well as we have all season.“We should have won the game and I felt we were the better team for most of it.“To not get the three points was disappointing but the manager said it’s definitely something to build on and we’ll look to do that.“When you are where we are in the table, the ball doesn’t seem to drop for you but you have to keep fighting through it.“The manager told us that Saturday was the standard now – we need to stick to it and make sure it doesn’t go below that.”The Dark Blues head into the international break still bottom of the Premiership with just four points to their name after picking up just their second result of the season.Despite their very poor start to the campaign, the players still have belief they can get themselves out of trouble and the work they’ve been doing under new boss Jim McIntyre will pay idends.“It’s still there, the players believe in what we are doing, that showed against St Mirren and everyone is buying into it, so I feel like it’s just a matter of time,” added Ralph.“The intensity has been really high in training and the manager definitely demands hard work.“I think we showed that on Saturday.“We’ve got the international break now and I feel like it would have been good to have another game this week and keep the momentum going. However, we’ll definitely be working on things over the next couple of weeks and look to improve on Saturday’s performance.”Ralph was something of a surprise inclusion against the Buddies, having been missing from first-team action since the end of August with a damaged hamstring tendon.The former Woking man admits he had a slow start to le at Dens Park in his opening games but put on an impressive show in just his third league appearance for the club.The left-back was strong in the air, confident on the ball and an attacking threat throughout Saturday’s - draw.The -year-old admits he was blowing a bit by the end after a tough game but was delighted to get a first  minutes under his belt in over two months.“It had been a while but it felt good to be back out there and, with the slow start I’d had at Dundee, it was nice to have a decent performance as well,” added the former Yeovil Town man.“It would have been nice to get the win, too, but you can’t have everything.“I felt alright by the end, not as bad as I thought I might be having been out so long.“It was just about getting through that first  minutes and it’ll get better from here.“It’s never nice to be sitting on the sidelines, especially with the way the results have been going. You feel like you want to help out where you can and obviously being injured, you can’t.“It had been a long time doing that so it felt good to be back out there and help us get a point on the board.“We need to build on that now.”

title: strike could see flights from dundee airport grounded
story: Flights at Dundee Airport could be grounded unless a strike by air traffic controllers can be averted.Controllers working for Highlands and Islands Airports , which runs Dundee’s facility, are demanding a % pay rise, which they say would bring their pay into line with other air traffic controllers in the UK.However, HIAL has offered the same % rise it gave to all staff. Trade union Prospect said there is near- unanimous support for industrial action. It will meet with HIAL management for further talks.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: “HIAL rates of pay have fallen signicantly behind the other air traffic providers in the UK.”A HIAL spokesman said: “Hial made a pay award offer to all staff which was accepted following an overall ballot of trade union members. Prospect ATC members were balloted separately and rejected the settlement.”

title: tom duthie false dawns could be over for arabs as current dundee united team showing grit and determination
story: As their team has struggled to get back to the Premiership, the last two-and-a-half years have seen Dundee United fans become used to  dawns.Under Ray McKinnon, by the end of  the Tangerines had battled back from a slow start to their first season in the Championship to move to the top of the ision and looked every inch automatic promotion contenders.It didn’t last and the next couple of months saw them slip off the pace and have to concentrate their efforts in getting up via the end-of-season promotion play-offs.It was a case of lightning striking twice a year ago when Csaba Laszlo took over.For a couple of months, United again looked the part only to quickly fall away with a string of horrible results that left them again facing the lottery of those post-season knockout games.The memories of those campaigns are why many Arabs are trying their damnedest not to get carried away by the progress their team’s been making since another new manager, Robbie Neilson, took charge last month.After a run of four wins and a draw, keeping feet firmly planted on the ground must be growing increasingly dficult. For the -plus who travelled to watch the weekend win at Ross County, it might be well nigh impossible.Because at the Global Energy Stadium on Saturday, Neilson’s Tangerines looked every inch the kind of side that finish top of this notoriously dficult of leagues. That was largely down to there being nothing pretty about this win.Under McKinnon, Laszlo and even Neilson already, United have shown when it comes to quality football,everything clicks there’s not a team in the second tier who can live with them.They can pass any side off the park, keep possession and conjure enough chances to comfortably win a game.For all but a few sides with genuine aspirations to win the Championship, however, that’s seldom enough. This is a ision where the team finishing first must also have the ability to grind out wins.It’s what St Mirren did last season, Hibs the one before and even Rangers found they had to be able to do as they got up two years ago.Even Neilson’s young Hearts side that galloped away with the title in  did, on the few occasions when necessary, show they could dig deep and battle for points.Now, and arguably for the first time since they dropped down from the top flight, it’s a quality United possess.They ended County’s nine-game unbeaten home run since the start of the campaign, not through playing the kind of football of which we know they’re capable, but by standing up to the physical challenge that’s always posed by the home side up there.Yes, United had to do plenty defending, but through a clear game plan, organisation and a willingness of players to put their bodies on the line, it was executed so well that, for all their territorial dominance, the Staggies had very few clear sights of goal.A nice bonus stemming from that fact was, for the first time in his short tenure, in the build-up to the game injuries were a signicant issue.Frederic Frans and Callum Booth were doubts last week and unable to train with the rest of the squad until a Friday session confirmed they wouldn’t make it. In William Edjenguele and Paul Watson, the manager found able deputies.He’s said since he arrived at Tannadice winning promotion would take a squad of highly committed players.He now knows he has that and try as they might not to, the fans must be getting excited.

title: tonight dundees glen kamara buzzing to build on first international goal
story: After opening his international goal account last time out, Glen Kamara is “buzzing” to have the chance to help Finland qualy for the Nations League play-offs.The -year-old fired in his first-ever senior goal as his country saw off Greece - last month in Tampere to keep up their % record in League C Group Two.The Finns head to Athens tonight needing just a point to confirm their promotion to League B after a superb run that’s seen them yet to concede a goal in their four matches that’s also seen a home-and-away double over Estonia.The team’s successes over the past few months are in complete contrast to his club season at Dundee this campaign.With the Dark Blues languishing at the foot of the Premiership table and goals few and far between, manager Jim McIntyre has urged his midfield to provide more goal threat.And Kamara, who has been pushed further forward by his new boss lately, says he has ambitions to add some club goals to his single international effort.“I’d say I’ve had about one shot in my time at Dundee!” the former Arsenal man said.“I definitely need to shoot more and try to help out the team with goals, it is something I’m working on.”And despite firing in a goal for his country that sealed victory over the Greeks, Kamara wasn’t overly proud by the quality of his first touch.He said: “What was the goal like  Don’t watch it!“I made a really bad touch into a good touch and a finish.“It was great, something I didn’t expect but I was buzzing after it.“It’s a great feeling to score for your country and we got a - win over Greece as well.“They are coming up again so we’ll have to be ready again.”Ranked th in the world and below upcoming opponents Greece and Hungary in the world rankings, the Finns’ record of four wins from their first four Nations League games have surprised onlookers.However, Kamara insists nobody within the camp is surprised at how well they’ve fared.Under manager Markku Kanerva, the Eagle Owls as they are nicknamed, have spread their wings and begun to fly after years in the international wilderness following the retirement of former Ajax great and Liverpool forward Jari Litmanen.That’s despite a lack of household names with Norwich striker Teemu Pukki most likely to be known to football fans on these shores after an unsuccessful spell at Celtic.Momentum is building, however, and the Finns will be hopeful of finding a backdoor route to Euro  through winning their Nations League group.That needs at least one point from tonight’s trip to Athens or the game against Hungary in Budapest on Sunday.Kamara said: “The team is in a good place, the manager is doing well and they are a good group of boys.“Things are going well in the Nations League and we have a good chance of winning our group.“We have Greece and Hungary up this week and with a win I’d say we’ll top the group.“That’s maybe surprised a few people but the team knew we were good enough after playing a few games together and,you watch us, you can see we are at a good level right now.”Kamara’s Dundee team-mate Benjamin Kallman has also featured for the full national side this year, though is more often involved with the U  squad.He remains at Dens Park this week as the young Finns don’t have any fixtures scheduled.
